description: From Old French detriement, from Latin detrimentum (“loss, damage, literally a rubbing off”), from dēterere (“to rub off, wear”), from dē- (“down, away”) + terere (“to rub”).
Detriment is based off the word deter, and built on similar foundations to the word impediment.

examples: "Would it be fair to say that when it came to making trouble, you'd make up for what you didn't absolutely know . . . and to our detriment?"

entries.meaning: (UK, obsolete) A charge made to students and barristers for incidental repairs of the rooms they occupy.

verbs.description: detriment (third-person singular simple present detriments, present participle detrimenting, simple past and past participle detrimented)

entries.meaning: (transitive, chiefly obsolete) To be detrimental to; to harm or mar.
